source: Indian Literature Archive - period metadata export

periods.name: Vedic Period
periods.description: The Vedic Period marks the composition of the Vedas and associated ritual literature. Oral mnemonic traditions, sacrificial praxis, and the earliest philosophical questions (proto-Upanishadic thought) are central.
periods.researchNotes: Focus on oral-formulaic features, accentuation, comparative Indo-European correspondences, and ritual praxis. Paleolinguistic and archaeological correlations may refine dating.

periods.name: Epic Period
periods.description: Epic narratives such as the Mahabharata and Ramayana consolidate mytho-historical frameworks, combined ritual material and social codes into epic genres that informed law, polity, and narrative traditions.
periods.researchNotes: High interest in recensional variation, interpolations, and oral/performance traditions. Use comparative philological methods for textual layers.

periods.name: Classical Period
periods.description: Classical Sanskrit saw the flowering of kavya poetry, dramatic traditions, and treatises on poetics and grammar, including seminal figures like Kalidasa, Bharata, and Pāṇini.
periods.researchNotes: Study poetic devices, metre, and dramaturgy; compare with regional classical developments in Tamil and Prakrit traditions.

periods.name: Medieval Period
keyWorks: Silappadikaram (Tamil epic, earlier composition, medieval commentary tradition)
periods.description: A period of intense regional literary activity: vernacular literatures matured, devotional currents flourished, and manuscript cultures diversified across polities.
periods.researchNotes: Manuscript collation is essential; region-specific palaeography and scripts must be considered. Interreligious dialogues (Bhakti/Sufi) are a growing research field.

periods.name: Bhakti Movement
periods.description: The Bhakti movement produced vernacular devotional poetry and practices that emphasized personal devotion and often challenged social hierarchies.
periods.researchNotes: Performance contexts and oral transmission are crucial. Investigate musical settings and kirtan traditions alongside textual versions.

periods.name: Sufi & Perso-Arabic Traditions
periods.description: Sufi poets and Persian literary traditions influenced subcontinental languages, producing mystical lyricism and hybrid literary cultures.
periods.researchNotes: Translation from Persian and Urdu requires sensitivity to demographic performance contexts; examine khanqah/ shrine based transmission.

periods.name: Early Modern & Colonial
keyWorks: Early newspapers, reformist tracts, early novels & periodical literature
periods.description: The arrival of print and colonial institutions transformed textual economies: newspapers, periodicals, and modern literary genres emerged, reshaping readership and textual authority.
periods.researchNotes: Newspapers and periodicals are essential for social history; digitization projects often yield fragmented runs—work with library holdings to reconstruct serials.

periods.name: Modern & Contemporary
keyWorks: Modern poetry, novelistic traditions, translation movements, digital humanities outputs
periods.description: Contemporary literatures are plural; digital methods (TEI, corpora, DH) and debates about translation ethics and canonization shape current research.
periods.researchNotes: Digital humanities tools are central—consider data licensing and ethical reuse when working with modern corpora.
